questions.text: Which of the following is the most common primary soft tissue malignancy of the foot?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Synovial cell sarcoma Although primary cutaneous melanoma is the most common malignant tumour of any type in the foot (acral lentiginous melanoma), the most common primary soft tissue malignant tumour in the foot is synovial sarcoma . They are often seen as soft tissue swelling with calcification on plain radiographs. The characteristic histological feature is a biphasic pattern with an epithelial component and a spindle cell component.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a chordoma involving the sacrum?

options.label: C
options.text: En bloc surgical resection with negative margins

options.label: D
options.text: Intralesional resection followed by radiation therapy

questions.correct_answer: C. En bloc surgical resection with negative margins
questions.explanation:
Solution:

En bloc surgical resection with negative margins Chordomas are very resistant to radiotherapy and chemotherapy; therefore, en bloc resection with a negative margin is the preferred treatment.

Highyeild:

Chordoma It is a rare neoplasm It arise from notochord remnants It is 2nd most common primary malignancy of spine after myeloma and most common primary malignancy of sacrum Usually seen in 5th to 7th decade at sacrum and 4th to 6th decade for sphenopalatine lesions Male>Female Greater than 50% of chordoma arise in the sacrococcygeal area and more than 30% arise at base of skull Complaints Headache, features of cranial nerve compression and low back ache usual clinical feature Radiographic findings Arise from midline and appear as a destructive lesion CT is used for calcification MRI for extension into soft tissue and other structures Treatment Wide surgical resection is primary treatment.

questions.text: The best chemical for extended curettage is which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Liquid N2 Liquid nitrogen technique in a GCT of the lateral femoral condyle. After the curettage of the tumor, liquid nitrogen is applied on the tumor bed through a stainless steel funnel, protecting the surrounding soft tissue with gelfoam layers Liquid N2 with a 1-cm zone of lysis is the most potent (Best) chemical used for extended curettage Extended curettage is used for benign / locally aggressive lesions in the bone which have recurrence so after scooping the lesion (Curettage). Additional chemical treatment is given to lyse the residual cells this is called as extended curettage. Liquid N2 with a 1-cm zone of lysis is the most potent (Best). Also used are H2O2 / PMMA. The most commonly used is phenol.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. H2O2 is used for extended curettage, but is not the most potent chemical Option: B. Phenol is a commonly used chemical in extended curettage Option: D. PMMA is used for extended curettage, but is not the most potent chemical

questions.text: Which of the following are Histological features of osteosarcoma?

options.label: B
options.text: Large stromal cells resembling osteoblasts with malignant characteristics like anisocytosis, nuclear pyknosis, pleomorphism

options.label: C
options.text: Direct formation of tumour osteoid and bone by the malignant connective tissue¬

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above These tumors penetrate and destroy the cortex of the bone and extend into surrounding soft tissues. In conventional intramedullary osteosarcoma , the predominant histologic pattern may be osteoblastic, fibroblastic, chondroblastic, giant cell rich, malignant fibrous histiocytoma like or partially telangiectatic.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. The tumour contains malignant cartilage and fibrous tissue in variable amounts Option: B. Osteosarcoma shows Large stromal cells resembling osteoblasts with malignant characteristics like anisocytosis, nuclear pyknosis, pleomorphism¬ Option: C. Although the histological features are variable, the absolute criteria for diagnosis are sarcomatous stroma and direct formation of tumour osteoid and bone by the malignant connective tissue therefore the tumour must always contain directly formed neoplastic osteoblastic areas to Qualify as an osteogenic sarcoma

questions.text: The CT image of 48 years old woman with presenting complaint of backache is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? The characteristic finding of 'Corduroy' appearance on radiological imaging is a characteristic feature of which of the likely condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hemangioma The image shows a classical polka dot sign and a corduroy sign. These are seen in vertebral hemangioma. This occurs due to the replacement of normal cancellous bone by thickened vertical trabeculae.

Highyeild:

Hemangioma It is common benign bone lesion which is usually a incidental finding and seen in spine > skull and pelvis. It consists of vascular channels capillary, venous or cavernous. In spine characteristic appearance is presence of thickened vertical orientated trabeculae (Corduroy appearance) of vertebral body, and increased density. Described as "jail house appearance" On CT cross section these thickened trabeculae have a "polka dot pattern" Treatment is not necessary always for symptomatic lesion extended curettage can be done for inoperable lesion low dose radiation can be used but there is risk of malignant degeneration

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Eosinophilic Granuloma Corduroy Appearance Not Seen In Ossifying Fibroma Option: C . Vertebral Metastasis: Corduroy Appearance Not Seen Option: D . Ossifying Fibroma: Corduroy Appearance Not Seen

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented in the OPD with the chief complaint of pain in the left upper arm and a history of trivial falls. Diagnosis of the unicameral bone cyst was made. A Unicameral bone cyst presents most often present as which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fracture through the cyst A unicameral bone cyst is most often symptomatic and presents following a fall and a fracture through the cyst wall. This is called pathological fractures. First 2 decades (M>F) Metaphysis Proximal humerus > Femur (MC) Adults: Ilium, Calcaneum (MC sites) Active: Distance b/w cyst and physis < 1 cm Latent: -------- // ‒‒‒‒‒‒‒‒‒‒> 1 cm Most active during skeletal growth → heal spontaneously True cysts (lined by epithelium < 1mm) Fluid contains PGE2 X-ray: Cyst is eccentric to central, purely lytic Well marginated Fallen fragment sign Aspirate: Clear serous fluid; H/D trauma - Blood Treatment: Aspiration → Steroid Sclerosants Curettage + BG

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. UBC are non-neoplastic, serous fluid-filled bone lesions most commonly found in proximal humerus Option: C. UBC are not associated with distal neurovascular deficits Option: D. Night pains are not seen in UBC, UBC are asymptomatic unless pathological fracture occurs

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding non-ossifying fibroma?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a developmental defect in which a nest of fibrous tissue appears in bone and persists

options.label: B
options.text: Commonest sites are metaphysis of long bones

options.label: C
options.text: There is a high risk for malignant transformation

options.label: D
options.text: If the defect is large may require curettage and bone grafting

questions.correct_answer: C. There is a high risk for malignant transformation
questions.explanation:
Solution:

There is a high risk for malignant transformation Non-ossifying fibroma is a developmental defect commonly encountered in children and an incidental finding on X-ray the commonest sites are the metaphyses of long bones occasionally there are multiple lesions, the X-Ray appearance is characteristic there is a radiolucent area surrounded by a thin margin of dense bone. Views in different planes show that the lesion appears to be central and is actually adjacent to or within the cortex, hence the alternative name 'fibrous Cortical Defect'. There is no risk of malignant transformation.

Highyeild:

Non Ossifying Fibroma/Fibrous Cortical Defect It is the commonest benign lesion of bone found in approximately 35% of all children's but this is not considered a true tumor and these are usually incidental findings Histologically, the defect is filled with spindle-shaped cells distributed in a whorled or storiform pattern. There is fibroblastic proliferation with high cellularity. Giant cells and foam cells are almost always apparent On plain radiographs, a nonossifying fibroma appears as a well-defined lobulated lesion located eccentrically in the metaphysis. Multilocular appearance or ridges in the bony wall, sclerotic scalloped borders, and erosion of the cortex are frequent findings Clinical presentation They develop in metaphysis of long bones particularly femur and tibia. And mostly adjacent to or with in the cortex (i.e. are eccentric), hence the name fibrous cortical metaphyseal endosteal defect. Majority lesion involves distal femur and tibia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Non-ossifying fibroma is a developmental defect commonly encountered in children Option: B. commonest sites for NOF are the metaphyses of long bones Option: D. Large NOF defects may require curettage and bone grafting

Solution:

Ribs It is a rare neoplasm It arise from notochord remnants It is 2nd most common primary malignancy of spine after myeloma and most common primary malignancy of sacrum Usually seen in 5th to 7th decade at sacrum and 4th to 6th decade for sphenopalatine lesions Male>Female Greater than 50% of chordoma arise in the sacrococcygeal area and more than 30% arise at base of skull

Highyeild:

Complaints Headache, features of cranial nerve compression and low back ache usual clinical feature Radiographic findings Arise from midline and appear as a destructive lesion CT is used for calcification MRI for extension into soft tissue and other structures Treatment Wide surgical resection is primary treatment. Chordoma - This rare malignant tumour arises from primitive notochordal remnants. It affects young adults and usually presents as a slow-growing mass in the sacrum. However, it may occur elsewhere along the spine (the cervical spine is most common) The most common presentation is backache X-ray features - radiolucent lesion, bone destruction is the only hallmark feature of this tumour Treatment - complete excision with radiotherapy

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presented with a chief complaint of progressive pain and swelling over his left leg. Diagnosis of osteosarcoma was made. Osteosarcomas occur most commonly at which of the following site?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lower end of femur This tumour is predominantly found in the metaphyseal region of long bones and very rarely in the mid-shaft region. The lower end of the femur upper end of the tibia and upper end of the humerus are involved in decreasing order of frequency. lower end of the femur > upper end of the tibia > upper end of the humerus

questions.text: An elevated level of prostaglandin PGE2 has been noted in the fluid aspirated from which of the following cyst?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Unicameral bone cyst An elevated level of prostaglandin PGE2 in the fluid aspirated from radiologically active unicameral bone cysts has been reported by several observers. The level of PGE2 is reduced after the injection of steroids. PGE2 is believed to stimulate the osteoblasts to resorb the bone.

Highyeild:

Simple/Solitary/ Unicameral-Bone Cyst This lesion is also considered a developmental or reactive lesion than a true tumor Features Mostly occurs during first two decades of life. Males>Females.. Arise in juxta physeal metaphysis and sometimes extends upto diaphysis but never cross physis to involve epiphysis and joint. Most common site proximal humerus (50%) and femur (25%). In adult ilium and calcaneum are more common locations Activity of the UBC can be judged on the x-ray by measuring the distance between the cyst and the physis. Active - Distance between the cyst and the physis less than 1 cm. b. Latent - Distance between the cyst and physis 1 cm These are most active during skeletal growth and heal spontaneously at maturity less than1 mm It is a true cyst (lined by epithelium) Fluid contains high level of PG-E2 Than the physis, minimal or no X Ray: Cyst is central, purely lytic lesion with a well marginated outline smaller periosteal reaction and most important is Fallen leaf (fallen fragment) sign which is pathognomic x-ray finding. Fallen leaf (fragment) sign Aspirate contain clear serous fluid unless there is a pathological fracture Treatment: aspiration and injection steroid, bone marrow or sclerosants are used. Curretage and bone grafting is also treatment option.(contraindicated in active lesion). Radiotherapy is contraindicated
